name: Trazodone
summary: Trazodone is an antidepressant often used to treat major depressive disorder, insomnia, and certain anxiety disorders.
description: Trazodone, marketed under the brand name Desyrel among others, is an antidepressant that acts primarily as a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI). It is FDA-approved for the treatment of major depressive disorder in adults, but is also widely prescribed off-label for insomnia and anxiety due to its sedative properties. Trazodone modulates serotonin activity in the brain and has additional alpha-adrenergic and histamine receptor blocking effects. Its sedative action is thought to be related to its antihistaminic and alpha-1 adrenergic blocking properties.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to trazodone or formulation components
Concurrent use with MAOIs or within 14 days of MAOI therapy

items: Treatment of major depressive disorder in adults

sections.text: Blocks serotonin 5-HT2 receptors and inhibits serotonin reuptake, increasing serotonin activity in the CNS. Also blocks alpha-1 adrenergic and histamine H1 receptors, contributing to sedative effects.

adult.oral: Depression: Initial 150 mg/day in divided doses; may increase by 50 mg/day every 3–4 days to a maximum of 400 mg/day (outpatients) or 600 mg/day (inpatients).
adult.low_dose_sleep: For insomnia (off-label): 25–50 mg at bedtime; may increase to 100 mg at bedtime if needed and tolerated.

geriatric.oral: Start at lower end of dosing range; for insomnia, 25 mg at bedtime, increasing cautiously.

sections.text: Antidepressant effect may take 2–4 weeks; sedative effects occur within hours.

other: May cause orthostatic hypotension and syncope
Risk of serotonin syndrome with serotonergic agents
Priapism is a rare but serious adverse effect
May cause sedation; caution with activities requiring alertness

sections.pregnancy: Limited data; use only if benefit justifies risk
sections.lactation: Excreted in human milk; caution advised
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to sedation and orthostatic hypotension; use lower doses

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over 1–2 weeks to minimize withdrawal symptoms.

items: Often chosen for depressed patients with prominent insomnia
Lower doses tend to be more sedating due to antihistaminic effects
Educate patients about priapism risk and need for urgent medical attention if it occurs
